Comments: This cover sheet has been added by SIAM to identify the winning team after judging was completed. Any identifying information other than team \# on an M3 Challenge submission is a rules violation.

Assumption: Since this problem concerns meal plans for students in school, we assume that refers to elementary through high schoolers; thus we are restricting our input ages from 6–18 years.
To calculate how different activities affect caloric requirements, we assume that during physical activity or sleep the rate of caloric burn holds constant over the entire period of activity.
Survey responses reflect daily habits that hold true on average.
At each meal, an individual eats until he or she is fully satiated or until the food runs out.
We assume that the calories consumed at a meal are equivalent to the calories burned since the last full meal (minus any snacks consumed in the interim period).
The caloric consumption of an individual is equivalent to the number of calories burned per day.
Model: Total Calories Burned \= (integral from 0 to 24 of R(t) dt) \* weight
Total Calories Burned \= (λs(Q1) \+ λlA(Q3i \- Q1) \+ λA(Q3f \- Q3i) \+ λlA(Q5i \- Q3f) \+ λA(Q5f \- Q5i) \+ λlA(Q7 \- Q5f) \+ λs(24 \- Q7)) \* weight
Lunch Calories \= (λs(Q1) \+ λlA(Q3i \- Q1) \+ λA(Q3f \- Q3i) \+ λlA(Q4 \- Q3f)) \* weight \- snacks  (if student eats breakfast)
Lunch Calories \= (λs(Q1) \+ λlA(Q3i \- Q1) \+ λA(Q3f \- Q3i) \+ λlA(Q4 \- Q3f) \+ λs(Q6 \- Q4) \+ λlA(Q7 \- Q6) \+ λs(24 \- Q7)) \* weight \- snacks (if student does not eat breakfast)
Results: Model tested against EER method, with an average percent error of 11.51% over the data set.
Sensitivity Analysis: Model demonstrated highest sensitivity to breakfast behavior.
Model was partially sensitive to weight, wake-up time, and bedtime.
Model was least sensitive to the amount of exercise.

Assumption: A student eating the standard school meal consumes the entire meal which contains the maximum caloric content as regulated by federal guidelines. The maximum caloric content of a high school lunch is 850 calories (Yee 2012).
As long as the caloric consumption of a student at lunch is within 15% of their calculated need, their dietary needs will be considered to be satisfied.
Model: Lunchtime calorie needs calculated using the model from Part 1.
Frequency distribution of lunchtime caloric needs generated from a sample of 11,458 high school students.
Results: Only 37.3% of all students would be satisfied by an 850-calorie lunch.
A 1,050-calorie meal would satisfy a greater number of students (49%).
Breakfast eaters have a much higher satisfaction rate (68%) than breakfast skippers (0.07%).

Assumption: Schools always strive to implement the recommendations of the USDA MyPlate to the best of their abilities. This consists of having 30% of each meal be composed of grains, 30% vegetables, 20% fruits, 20% proteins (by number of servings), and one serving of dairy (Moore).
Schools choose to deliver the best meals possible given their budgets and may never exceed their budgets.
Schools make meals that deliver the number of calories determined by our model in Part 1.
Schools serve lunch five times a week.
It is possible to give fractional servings of every menu item.
Model: Costs\_total \= Costs\_grain \* Servings\_grains \+ ..., or Costs\_total \= Costs\_grain \* 0.3 \* Servings\_total \+ ...
Results: Algorithm generates meals that meet USDA MyPlate requirements, have the necessary number of calories, and fit the available school budget.
Meals ranked based on student acceptance.
Example meals and rankings provided for a simulated menu.
Strength and Weakness: Our model specializes in determining the number of calories a student needs to consume for lunch, taking into account factors such as breakfast habits and snacking patterns that are often not considered in typical calorie calculators.
Our model can be easily customized to local regions using the included survey.
Our model is able to provide a set of meals to cafeterias that will be well liked by students while also meeting nutrition and budgetary restrictions.

We assume that at each meal a student eats until they are fully satiated. However, due to time constraints a person might not always have enough time to consume as much as they’d like especially in the morning.
We also assume that rates of metabolic activity are constant in time periods as determined by our questionnaire.
Our meal-planning algorithm does not currently handle multicategory foods such as pizza (which contains grains, vegetables, and dairy).
Meal choices were made based on nutritious factors including MyPlate food category percentages and caloric needs but not based on considerations such as fat and sugar content.
